me buys game - :D
me plays game - :D
me compleats game - :◖
realizes there's 2 more games - :D
realizes  he has to pay for both - :◖.

-Can I shoot stuff please?

-No, you have to drive a crappy airboat and a stupid buggy for [b]half[/b] of the game.

-K, I'll go play Wreckfest instead then. Way better physics in that game anyway.

-Wait! I've got a bunch of bugs too, not just the annoying antlions. Actual game breaking bugs, like the A.I. disabling itself. So you can have fun messing with the console to fix it.

-Oh really? Count me in then.

Sarcasm aside, can't wait to finish the main game, which hasn't aged well at all, even with the Cinematic Mod, to at last continue with the 2 Episodes. Which if I remember correctly, are better.

UPDATE: Okay now missing textures that are un-fixable by verifying cache or by console. I quit. F*ck this game. And no, don't blame it on Cinematic Mod, as searching on the web, some people without the mod are having those issues also. F*ck you Valve. Wasted my time once again.

겨울 세일 때 에피2까지 1500원에 팔아서 바로 구매했습니다.
출시 당시에는 물리엔진이 확실히 획기적이었지만... 나온지 오래돼서 이곳 저곳 옛날 게임이라는 느낌이 많이 듭니다. 지금봐도 짱짱한 그래픽의 크라이시스1과 약간 비교되는 부분이라고 할까요.
개인적으로 1인칭, 3인칭 슈팅 게임들을 게임 패드로 즐기는데(주된 이유는 진동 때문이지만), HL 시리즈는 패드관련 최적화를 안해서 그런지 멀미가 굉장히 심합니다. 아마 직접 조준감도를 조정하면 멀미가 좀 나아질 거라 생각합니다.

Half Life 2. Cosi bello. Questa saga mi ha fatto imparare cosa vuol dire fare un gioco e renderlo originale. Quando chiedo alla gente se conosce half life e loro rispondono di 'no', vedevo persone fissate ai giochi popolari e non giochi fatti bene, ma va bene cosi. Perchè? Non voglio che half life faccia la fine di Cod o di cs go. Half life è vita. Half life è tutto per me. A me non interessa che questa saga sia non popolare. La popolarità non rende il suo gioco. Guardate che fine ha fatto fortnite, una czzo di macchina per fare soldi ecco cosa è. Perfino half life Alyx sta solo a £46 e la valve si è fatta un culo cosi per fare il gioco e inventare nuove innovazioni.

10/10    grazie valve per avermi dato una passione.

Perfect crossover between action FPS and narrative. I played this back in 2007/08 probably and was blown away by the quality of everything, a masterpiece. Best is it still holds in 2020. Still playable and amazing.

[i]Half-Life 2[/i] is a truly unique masterpiece of an adventure, one that shook the video game scene to its very core the moment it came out.

When you hear people rave over this game and the series as a whole, people from the outside have no reference for how truly fantastic it is, and plenty will dismiss it as an overrated title and never end up experiencing it for themselves. While it is slightly overrated when described as a sort of "pinnacle of gaming", it still is an awe-inspiring masterpiece and is up there with the very best the medium has to offer. As with all great franchises and pieces of art, the sequel to the original [i]Half-Life[/i] vastly experimented and went in a completely different direction, one that sets these games apart tremendously in many respects, besides quality. Where [i]Half-Life[/i] is a turbulent escape from the [i]Black Mesa[/i] facility with a more action-oriented focus, [i]Half-Life 2[/i] is a rebellious uprising experienced through the eyes of the highly respected [i]Gordon Freeman[/i] twenty years after the [i]Black Mesa[/i] incident, filled with newly introduced physics puzzles and properties that truly set it apart from anything else you would have played in the time when this video game behemoth came out. 

Although I am one who at the time of writing this review prefers [i]Half-Life[/i] over its sequel, it is one of those situations where I completely understand the preference of one or the other and have no problem with someone disagreeing on this front, it's just comparing a masterpiece to a masterpiece that both have so many different things to offer. The themes of [i]Half-Life 2[/i] are ones that we have seen countless times throughout literature and media: the rebellion of those who feel oppressed by their oppressors that feel they are themselves doing what is best for mankind, which ultimately leads to many skirmishes fought across the land until the assumed figurehead clashes with the empiric oppressor's leader in a final battle of ideals. A popular set-up, for sure, but an effective one at that. It helps us to relate to the characters in their struggle, and immediately turn you to their side. Other techniques, such as dehumanizing the enemies in the form of the [i]Combine[/i] and fitting them all with matching uniforms allows us to dissociate with their cause and not question their motives, which seem hellbent on the oppression of mankind after the incident at [i]Black Mesa[/i]. Whether their or [i]Wallace Breen's[/i] cause is justified to the player or not, they fill their roll as most anyone would in the situation [i]Gordon Freeman[/i] is in.

With an arguably universal theme to work with, the humanity and compassion the characters are filled with really help you to care about their struggle and merge with your role for as long as you are [i]Freeman[/i] himself. The rebellion theme alone would not necessarily make this an unforgettable and unique video game experience, but [i]Valve[/i] masterfully crafted these people and the game in its entirety to come to an end product with limitless influence and adventure. The main draw to this series, at least for me, is always the gameplay. It truly feels like nothing else outside of the games this company makes. The fluid, satisfying controls, the creative arenas and enemies you face off against, and so on. What I will definitely give this game over the first is its sheer uncontrollable expanse of experimental gameplay styles littered throughout. The gravity gun alone changed the way this game worked from every other previous first-person shooter out there, but additions like the many usable vehicles and unique weapons added so much to make this untouchable in the grander scheme of video gaming, especially at the time it came out.

This is truly a game everyone should experience at some point in their lives, it holds so much in the span that it runs that it can barely contain itself in its own ambition, but luckily it led to a couple of episodes being released afterwards to accommodate the ending and allow the game and its story to continue blowing away audiences as it reaches new climaxes and sets the standard for video games continuously. This is a sequel that truly stands toe-to-toe with its predecessor, and in many ways, surpasses it. Had I not held such a love for the first game, I would have admitted that this game is the truly better entry overall, but for now I have to say both are spectacular and equal masterpiece material for everything both introduced into the video game scene the moment they both released the years they did. It is undeniable that [i]Valve[/i] has created one of, if not, the best video game series to date with [i]Half-Life[/i] and [i]Half-Life 2[/i].

[b][RATING: 10/10][/b]

[b][Edit: After much reflection, this is undeniably the better game when pitting Half-Life and Half-Life 2 against each other, although this isn't to say Half-Life is not right up there with its sequel because it truly still is a masterpiece of a release, and again, still has the edge over Half-Life 2 in a few respects, but for my personal preference, I have to say this release comes out on top.][/b]
